description.text: These are training trucks for noobs like us who want to practice skateboard tricks without all that spookiness of actually rolling around. Live out your Tony Hawk dreams while begging your awkward, gangly extremities to learn how to friggin ollie. They've got a gentle rocker on the bottom so you can work on your sea legs and make the experience a little more real. You have been warned: On painted floors, these things are probably better for ice luge training than skateboarding. For a solid grip, keep them on carpet, wood, concrete, asphalt, etc... v0.6: Slightly larger around the screws for more strength and better stress distribution. More clearance for screws all around.

Printing
Print hot and thick. 3mm+ walls all around, 20% infill. To speed things up I changed my nozzle size in Cura to have the machine put down 0.6mm beads instead of 0.4mm. For extra printed freshness, print with all the filament scraps you have laying around, so that they come out with a little color in the mix. Still testing the best settings to make these things totally rugged. Assembly
I mounted mine with 30mm M5 bolts because metric is my jam. Standard #10-32 bolts probably work too. Pair it with this excellent and super cheap deck from Amazon for a nice budget setup:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002GIEAG4/ref=oh_details_o00_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

author: schonc

description.text:
So, I love my new microbits, and not just because I get to say I have a BBC-branded computer. However, those pins and contacts are not anywhere near as convenient as they should be. Yes, Banana plugs fit, but unless you only stick them in halfway, they just sort of wiggle about. Alligator clips are fine for testing, but I don't like how they bite into the PCB if you try to hook them through the holes, and if you simply apply them to the contacts, they can shift around and scratch things up, if not cause shorts across other contacts.

I went looking for cases or some other solutions apart from those breakout boards that Sparkfun and Monkmakes have produced, and came across this "neckbolt" cover. I do really like it, but there's a few parts of the design that personally irk me. That's not knocking @Vlastimil3 it's just he clearly has more confidence in his printers than I do. I like to avoid overhangs that require support. I also was a bit leery of using countersunk screws, because if the heads are a little too big, they may overlap with other pins, and that's what i wanted to avoid. So, I've made two variations on it.

Both involve an all-important backplate, protecting the contacts on both sides. This frees up the type of bolts you can use along with any additional hardware like nuts and washers. Still, be cautious about the surface you place it on, as metal will definitely create shorts. Maybe I'll make some protective caps depending on what type of bolts I settle on.

One forgoes the text labeling the ground and analog pins, but the other keeps it while adding the backplate. This allows you to print without supports while keeping the contacts covered. I didn't print an example of this one; the M3D is fine on simple shapes, but chokes on text when it comes to the rubbery filament I use.

author: Spooky1

description.text:
As I really like the idea of Masterspool, it botherd me, to invest around 250g of Filament and 15h of printingtime for every spool.
With all the Material and Electricity used for that, it's propably worse for the enviroment, than a standard injectionmolded Spool wich is recycled after use.

So I dicided to upcycle my old empty spools from dasFilament!

I cut them in half, sothat I can put refillpacks on them and with the printed cernel I close them back together.

The spool is cutted with an angle, sothat the halfs can't rotate relativly to each other and it makes seperating the halfes very easy, by removing the Bold and twisting the two spoolhalfs. They push apart on their own!

As dasFilament used two differend types of spools in the last years, I made differend Nuts, one for the older alphaplastic spools with 53mm ID and 55mm wide
And one for the newer Häfner-spools with 52.5mm ID and 53mm wide
But the fit of course every other spool with the same measurements.

Have fun using your upcycled empty Spool to save the enviroment!

Printer:

fullmetal P3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

3 Perimeters
3 Top and Bottom Layer
The fit of the nut in the Spool should be very tight! If it does not want to fit, smooth ist firmly with some sandpaper, but it shouldn't fall out from it's own weight!

author: Dbvandy

description.text:
This is a 4-piece office supply organizer that fits right on your desk! It has 4 separate pieces that fit nicely together, like a puzzle. You can make any configuration of the pieces, so it fits whatever supplies you need it to. There are 3 different models:

Pencil Holder:
The tallest one (about 8 1/2 cm tall) is shaped like a cup, so it can hold pencils, pens, rulers, etc.

Rubber Band Holder:
The one with a post sitting in the middle is used to hold rubber bands. The bands can be draped over the overhang, and any extra rubber bands can sit in the dish.

Paper Clip Holder:
The mostly-flat dish can be used to hold small items, for example, paper clips. It can also work for binder clips, pushpins, thumbtacks, erasers, etc.

In the versions I printed, I did one of each of the pencil and rubber band holder, and two paper clip holders. If you so choose, you can do all four paper clip holders, or two pencil holders and two rubber band holders. There's no limit on how many of each piece you create!

title: Anet A8 - Duet Wifi / Ethernet with Mosfet and 80mm Fan Mount

description.text:
This allows you to mount a Duet Wifi or Duet Ethernet board to your Anet A8.

It is designed for vertical mounting of the board at the original board's position. Because the Duet Wifi and Ethernet are cooled at the bottom of the PCB, it offers a 40mm offset from the printer's frame to allow optimal air flow.
Additionally an 80mm fan can be mounted to the bottom of the mount to guaranty best cooling. A wire guide is integrated to make sure no wires jam the fan.

Last but not least you may add a mosfet for the bed heater to it which is placed on the left hand side.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm - 0.3mm

Infill:

~25%

Required Additional Material
  • 4 M3 scews and nuts from the original board mounting.
  • 4 M4x10 screws for the board
  • 4 M3x5 screws for the mosfet
  • 4 mounting screws or pins for the fan
Installation Instructions

Step 1:
First make sure, all the electronics are connected to the Duet board. This should be done before mounting the board because some labels for the connectors are on the bottom of the PCB. If you know the board very well, you may do this after step 3.

Step 2:
Attach the 80mm fan to the mount using the supplied screws or pins. Do this now because you will not be able to reach all attachment points once the board is mounted.
Make sure, the blow direction is correct (towards the board).

Step 3:
Attach the mount to the printer frame using the original screws and nuts. Washers are recommended.

Step 4:
Attach the Duet board to the mount using the M4x10 screws. No nuts needed. Make sure to use the rubber washers supplied with the Duet board.

Step 5:
Attach the mosfet using the M3x5 screws. Fasten them softly!
If you do not have M3x5 screws, you may user longer screws like M3x10 using some washers under the head of each screw to. Do not try to turn longer screws all the way in or fasten them too tight or the Mount might break.

Step 6:
Make sure everything is connected propperly and especially that no shorts may occur.
Make sure no wires may touch the fan.
Make sure the Z axis can move freely up and all the way down. You may need to zip some wires together to keep them out of the way. Especially the X axis motos needs some extra space.

author: leo23

description.text: These mounts allow you to mount a license plate to the rear of your Porsche 991 without drilling holes in the bumper. They were designed on a 991.2 Turbo S, but should fit other 991s as well. You need to print two upper brackets, and both the left and right lower brackets. 3M Super Strong Automotive molding tape and hot-set 3D brass thread inserts are available from Amazon and elsewhere. Best to print in ABS or other heat-capable material (rather than PLA which tends to warp/melt in the hot sun). The tape will stick to the brackets much stronger if you acetone-smooth the mounting surface

title: Glass holder / clips for a round bed. BIQU

description.text:
Not sure if these will work on other printers but they are designed for the BIQU Plus/Pro style headed bed.

The holders have a slight bend to them to keep the glass in place under a bit of tension. The sliding clips can be used if needed to stop the heat lifting the glass or counter any warps in the heated bed that is causing the glass to rock.

The sliding clips have a taper to them to account for different glass thickness or glass with a build surface on.

title: MINI CNC with cdrom steppers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Still VERY VERY much a work in progress I uploaded only so you can bring your ideas to the project, The idea is to use heavy fishing line as belts and use pulley's system to help double the strength of weak of the cd-rom motors. I have created a grope for us to communicate and calibrate https://www.thingiverse.com/groups/minicnc

Rods I used are 7mm aluminum bar stock, which is easily found in any metal supplier shop, the threaded rods are 3/16 inch. the build plate should be a 1/8 acrylic sheet and the idea was to use double side tape to stick to the printed bearings and Y carriage block which I have not designed yet. also the X carriage will be a two part so it could easily be swapped for a pen or a laser or a small drill with servo.

title: Balloon Boat V3 UPDATE! - Compatible with Mini Figures
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi there again!

EDIT:
First of all: Thanks a lot to everybody who likes my balloon boat, to those who printed it and to those who gave me a little tip. It is just so amazing being featured on Thingiverse. When I woke up and saw the e-mail with the notification I couldnt't believe it.
Ok, back to work ;)
Why an edit?

Another small update:

  • Because some users asked for it: added a smaller version of V3.1
  • added a version without pins of V3.2 --> maybe it is better for people having trouble with air leaks. (But the problem for those is at first still the tube, not the pins).

UPDATE TIME!
What's new?

  • The "inner life" got's a new desgin. It is cleaner and the air will not leave the tube anymore.
  • V3.1 & V3.2 got a shorter chimney - faster print and more stability
  • The pin-rows are now even - Yipiee, Homer J. can sit just right in the middle of the boat!
  • The pins become a little bit thicker - so the blocks will fit even better.
  • V3.2 is a "classic" balloon boat with exhaust - it's easier for kids to inflate the balloon and in my opinion the boat is more stable on the water and faster.

Thanks to all for the good suggestions and thanks a lot to those who think it's worth a little tip for my next coffee when designing things :-)

Previous text:
Here is my new Version of "Balloon Boat" (V3). Now it is fully compatible with the famous mini-figures from Denmark.

Video: http://vimeo.com/254343120

It is also much more stable on the water than the older versions are.

Print it, try it and if you think it's worth it, I would be happy of a little tip.

  1. Put a balloon over the chimney and blow in the exhaust.
  2. Set the boat on top of water and release the "air hole".
  3. Have fun!

Link to V1+V2:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2735625

Greets

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

0.2

15 %

Print with 3 outlines.
User dbgeorge printed the boat with 4 top- and 4 bottom-layers. This will help a lot to get the boat fully air-tight.

comments.text: For those having issues with making it airtight, you might consider more top layers, but hotter temp and possible more extrusion could help as well. You can also adjust line width up to 0.48mm even with a .4mm nozzle. And consider using ironing in Cura 3.2, I think that will definitely seal horizontal surfaces.
comments.author: povlhp

comments.text: I gave this a try, but it leaks massively.  Like there's no way you can blow up the balloon.  To test where the air was coming out, I filled the balloon and then attached it and then put the whole thing under water and watched for bubbles.  And there were a LOT!  It is the Lego bumps that are doing it.
comments.author: bcsteeve

comments.text: I had two out of three leak exactly the same as you describe.  It does seem like the "studs" are where it comes out mainly, and looking at the design they are "hollow" inside and wish they were solid. However, the air shouldn't even be getting into the hull cavity in the first place. I am tempted to dissect the ones that leak to see how that is happening.
comments.author: bcsteeve

comments.text: Good point.  If this were traditional manufacturing, I'd say the mistake is the square angles of the tube that's holding the air.  "seams" should be avoided.  But does this translate to 3D printing?  Probably not so much.  The issue is probably a lot more basic... that 3D printed objects simply aren't airtight :)
comments.author: dbgeorge

comments.text: That is exactly where I suspected the leak was too, but I performed an autopsy and at first was surprised to find where it was, then it made sense.  On this one, it actually happened where the tube goes up the chimney. Looks like at the layer where the deck starts, it starts under-extruding there for some reason, and there was a square tube layer that basically had no adhesion. Maybe because it starts doing more travels, or maybe the square tube layers start cooling too much while it is doing the deck top/bottoms, or both.  Not too sure how to work around that during the print. I might try to fix my other leaker by drilling down the chimney just past the deck layer and printing a round tube to glue in.
comments.author: bcsteeve

comments.text: I did some searching regarding "3d print airtight" and it sounds like it is just a hopeless cause.  3d printed items are simply... porous.  Granted, for this type of thing, we don't really need airtight.  We need air-sorta-tight.  Which is why it works sometimes for some people with some settings.  I think the design could be improved.  More walls around that tube would help. 100% infill probably would help (but man, what a waste of plastic).
comments.author: dbgeorge

comments.text: I am not so sure about that, as I print stuff all the time that hold water such as vases and hummingbird feeder usually with just 3 perimeters that don't leak, but I guess that is "water tight".  Also, I switched to another balloon boat model where the pieces are separate and the chimney looks like a corncob pipe, and those are all coming out "air tight".
comments.author: bcsteeve

comments.text: water is much much (keep going) larger than air.  Like I said, we just need "sorta tight" so it can work, it just can't leak as bad as it is.  I'm sure this can be fixed.

title: CR-10S extruder relocation plate and filament sensor housing

description.text:
I relocated the extruder stepper 50mm to the right and 5mm to the back to move the incoming filament away from the Z-spindle and make room for a properly monted filament sensor housing.
The housing is made for the stock filament sensor that came with the CR-10S.

EDIT:
Since my new aluminum extruder has no more cable guide, I added one to the brace plate. And sice putting on the nuts was kind of a PITA i also added press fit seats for said nuts.

Some additional hardware will be needed:
M3x6 (5x) --> relocation brace to plate
M3x10 (2x) --> housing lid
M3x13 (4x) + M3 nuts (4x) + M3 washers(4x, optional) --> everything to original stepper location

title: Customizeable Wine Charms using spiff type, for use in OpenSCAD

description.text: Made these for a friends wine party - it is based on the file by rorleth (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:216658) but I really did not like the kerning (space between letters) of the standard type library, so I modified the code to use spiffsans by stuartpb (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:106256).

To create custom charms, you will need OpenSCAD (http://www.openscad.org/), along with spiff.scad and spiffsans.scad (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:106256). Place the spiffsans files in the same directory as this .scad file. The variables to change are at the beginning of this file once open in .scad - type in your text and compile. Because spiffsans does not return the length of the type, you will have to fidget with the characterwidth variable to get the tag back plate to the correct width.

title: PRUSA i3 Spool Easy Loader with bearings

description.text:
Easy loading ball bearing spool holder for PRUSA i3 and other printers. Spool spindle length / size optimized for Hatchbox and eSun filament spools (PLA, ABS, PETG, TPU)

A hybrid Remix of great designs by jasonalday and butchja:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2492772
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2070272

2 versions of main arm included, one for mounting on a 6.0mm thick PRUSA i3 plate, and another for a 6.65mm thick plate.

Hardware

(1) M8 x 45mm long bolt
(2) Skateboard wheel bearings 8x22mm

Assembly
1) insert one ball bearing down into the tube opening on threaded end of spool, press into seated position
2) insert M8 x 45mm bolt in same end of spool, that bearing in step 1 was inserted into
3) from opposite side of spool, press bushing spacer over M8 bolt, then press in remaining ball bearing
4) screw M8 bolt into spool holder arm, fully tighten, check for free rotating of spool .. loosen M8 bolt slightly to free bearings if required

description.text:
Slim wallet capable of holding two house keys. The pockets are designed to fit standard Schlage and Kwikset style keys which cover most standard home locks. Choose either two pockets for kwikset, two schalge, or one of each.

The wallet is held together with two hair bands which allow you to clip bills to the outside of the wallet.

If you don't want to store keys in your wallet, simply print two "wallet top" files and have a super slim wallet.

I designed this because I wanted an easy way to carry a spare house key in case I ever locked myself out, or to take with me when I wanted to carry as little as possible. Previously I used a metal slim wallet with rubber band purchased online, but this is lighter weight and the cotton hair ties don't "stick" to the inside of your pocket like rubber does.

remixed_from.author: enif
remixed_from.title: Flexing battery holders with integrated spring

title: AA Battery base for glowing moon

description.text:
This is a base with battery holder for the "Glowing moon".

This isn't actually a remix, but there should be a linking to the two objects this thing belongs to, to make sense:
Credits go to Brandon Zhun for his wonderful moon: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2531838
and to enif for his very versatile flexing battery holders: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456900

I wanted a simple base for the moon which can hold 2 AA cells as power supply for 2 low-current LEDs for the illumination.
So I designed a simple two-piece base which holds the battery case, has a 6mm hole for a standard mini rocker switch, and a snap-fit cover for easy access to the battery compartment.

*IMORTANT** I scaled the moon down to 75% which results in a diameter about 10cm=4" so the battery base has a diameter of 80 mm which might be a bit small for the original size of the "glowing moon" which is 140mm diameter.. You can scale the base up of course but: There is a writing on top, following the circle shape of the cover, which says "The moon 1:34.740.000" which - if i did my maths correct- is the scale factor for the 10cm-version.

If someone wants to print this and needs a different cover lettering, just drop me a line...

The illumination is made with 2 low-current-LEDs in warm white colour. All clear LEDs with the standard housing with the dome shape however produce a sharp, focussed beam. This is not what we want to make the moon glow, but its easy to fix: just use a file or sandpaper and file the dome flat, you can also sand the side parts of the LEDs to make them dull.
Et voila, the LED now gives diffused light.
I soldered two of them in parallel (faceing each other) and simply hung that wire construct inside the moon globe. Sorry i forgot to take pictures and i glued everything together meanwhile :-(

I checked power consumption; the two LEDs only consume about 6mA. With two standard alkaline cells with a typical capacity of 3000mA this moon would glow for about 500hours, which is about 20 days...

Note: of course you have to print the battery holder for 2 AAcells separately: https://www.thingiverse.com/download:763280

(At first i thought it might be a good idea to integrate this into the base bottom, but i think the wiring is more difficult and unconvenient then.)

Printer:

Creality Ender-2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

With a well calibrated printer, the cover snaps snuggly into the grove on the base part.

Assembly

Solder your LEDs, pull the wire trough the hole in the small part of the moon. Fix that wire with hot glue, then stick the wire through the hole in the base cover piece. Glue the moon with hot glue on top of the cover piece. Then wire your battery holder, the switch and press the cover gently on the base!

print_settings.Notes:: You can really use any infill you like.  I used a bit more on the guns, a bit less on the gemstones.

description.text:
My kid loves the game Robot Turtles. We both decided it would be more fun if we had actual 3D pieces to play with instead of just the cardboard tokens.

This is a multi-phase project.
Phase 1, Turtles and Gemstones: COMPLETE
Phase 2, Ice Walls and puddles: IN PROGRESS
Phase 3, Boxes: CANCELLED (I decided to go with this crate since my test print came out so well)
Phase 4, Stone/metal walls: NOT STARTED
Phase 5, Game piece storage: NOT STARTED

Printer:

Tevo Tornado

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You can really use any infill you like. I used a bit more on the guns, a bit less on the gemstones.

Everything was designed to fit quite snugly and stay without glue. If not, a little filing/cutting will make it fit. You may need a few taps with a rubber mallet. Remember, you want it to stay in without glue.

Phase 1

Turtles:
Found that someone else did some robot turtles already, but I didn't want the entire turtle to be colored the same. Went up one level to the turtle model they were remixed from and cut a hex-shaped hole in the top.

Then, with the game cards as a basic guide, I recreated the turtle's guns using OpenSCAD.

Gems:
I decided that simple/durable would be for the best (I expect my kid to be a kid after all) and just whipped up a base/top in a few minutes using OpenSCAD.

title: Shower Curtain Hooks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed these after getting frustrated with my store bought stainless steel shower hooks that rusted and stopped sliding. It took multiple design styles and revisions to get it right. I think you'll really enjoy these.

Print 1 ea.(Roller.STL) for each hook. Then choose either the (Single_Hook.STL) or the
(Double_Hook.STL) for showers with 2 curtains.

These actually roll really well and are a real improvement from the store bought "Stainless" hooks that rust over time.

**see the print settings below

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

see below

Infill:

see below

Notes:

Print Settings

  • Single Hook or Double Hook:
    Layer Height:0.2
    Fill Density:100%
    Print speed:40 (mm/s)
    Support:none

  • Roller:
    Layer Height:0.3
    Shell Thickness:0.8 (mm)
    Fill Density:25%
    Print speed:30 (mm/s)
    Support:none

Installation Instructions:

Step1: Test fit the roller into the prongs of the hook by separating the hook prongs just enough to slip the roller into the hook. I used a fingernail sanding file to round off the prongs a little. Sand the hook prongs just enough until the roller spins easily.**because the hooks are printed horizontally the may have a flat spot on one side, the idea is to sand the flat spot round.

Step 2: Slightly separate the top of the hook then slide it over the shower curtain rod.

Step 3: With the hook slid over the curtain rod separate the top of the hook again enough to slip the prongs into the roller hubs.
Fusion 360

comments.text: I suppose I could have used the customizer for different diameter shower rods. I don't think it's that important for the roller to be shaped to the exact size of the curtain rod. Only that it needs to be able to track like a kind of v-groove. Thanks for the feedback and enjoy. Let us know how they worked out.

print_settings.Notes:: Tech2c uses Cura in the video, where as I use simplify3d (and now that we mention them, I'm really pissed at their bad customer service and only partly support for linux). The process i slightly different, but it is still very easy. In simplify3d I set up two processes, one for the first 1,6 mm and one from 1,6 mm and upwards. Simplify3d adds lot of comment in the gcode file, so I could use a text editor to search for where process 2 started (search for "; process 2"), and manually inserted a new line with the M600 cgode.

description.text:
I wanted someway to help me remember which of my kegs had run out of beer. Of cause an "Out of service" sign was the most logical solution (or at least the first solution I thought of).

I designed the sign in openscad, so it should be easy to modify in you need something different.

Notes:

I printed these on my cr-10 without dual extruder. To do this, I started out with the printer loaded with the yellow filament. Then at 1,6 mm height, I paused the print and changed to the black filament.

The filament change was done by adding a M600 gcode in the sliced file. For more information see Tech2c's video on the subject:

https://youtu.be/Rh7VmjOLo0I

Tech2c uses Cura in the video, where as I use simplify3d (and now that we mention them, I'm really pissed at their bad customer service and only partly support for linux). The process i slightly different, but it is still very easy. In simplify3d I set up two processes, one for the first 1,6 mm and one from 1,6 mm and upwards. Simplify3d adds lot of comment in the gcode file, so I could use a text editor to search for where process 2 started (search for "; process 2"), and manually inserted a new line with the M600 cgode.

print_settings.Notes:: One of the images shows all the parts laid out on a bed, as though they were to be printed together. I don't recommend this, since some of the smaller parts (insert, washers, T-nuts) should be printed at 100% infill, while the larger parts (base and pin) can be printed with reduced infill of 30%, or even less if you choose. These are not highly stressed parts, so you can make the call.

description.text:
The whole point of this remix of wolfdog060's excellent (and very clean) brace design was to allow the use of very cheap Wal-Mart carbon fiber arrow shafts instead of the heavy and expensive aluminum rods he used.
Also, I was able to mod things to easily swap the whole assembly to the front of the printer, which made it compatible with the 'S' model of the CR-10, since his was made for the regular CR-10, which doesn't have the 2nd Z-axis lead screw on the right side.
I've modeled some additional small parts, allowing you to now print everything required for this project, with the exception of the carbon shaft itself, and a few common screws. See below for the full parts list.

Printer:

Creality CR-10S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.25 (part-specific)

Infill:

30-100% (part-specific)

Notes:

One of the images shows all the parts laid out on a bed, as though they were to be printed together. I don't recommend this, since some of the smaller parts (insert, washers, T-nuts) should be printed at 100% infill, while the larger parts (base and pin) can be printed with reduced infill of 30%, or even less if you choose. These are not highly stressed parts, so you can make the call.

Post Processing

Post-print clean up will be required on all parts to obtain the proper fit. Have an exact-o style knife and sandpaper handy. I used 320 grit for everything, since surface finish wasn't important to me.

Parts and Materials:

This list assumes you are making a brace for 1 side of your printer. Double accordingly if doing both sides.

Parts to buy (not print):

  • (1) Carbon Fiber arrow shaft from Wal-Mart. Get the cheap one. I don't have the actual part # right now, but the outer diameter is 0.302" (7.6mm). Bring your calipers and find the one that matches. You won't look weird at all. :) It should be around $3-4. It is NOT the really shiny one with the tip molded on. That's fiberglass and too small. The shaft should very light, have a matte gray/black finish, and no tip/point installed.

  • (4) M3 (3mm) x ~12mm screws. You can choose the head style and finish you prefer here. I used pan head zinc screws because I had them in my parts box. These are for the T-Nuts, so make sure you don't get them too long, or they'll bottom out in the track and won't tighten up. If they're too short, they won't protrude enough to engage the T-nuts. I had 12mm and they worked fine. YMMV.

  • (4) flat washers for M3 screws. These are optional. I had them, so I used them. Your call.

  • (2) 8-32 machine screws, head style and length of your choice. These are the ones that go into the ends of the carbon rod. They're 8-32 because that's the standard thread for an arrow tip insert, so you can use the factory end and only have to make one. If you prefer to keep everything metric, print and extra insert, cut both ends of the shaft, and use whatever screw you want. Length is not critical here, since the shaft is hollow. It could feasibly be 2" long, although that would be foolish. As long as it's long enough to fully engage the threads in the factory arrow insert (which are recessed), you're good. I used some I had that were about 1" long. They were a bit longer than required but worked just fine.

Parts to print:
(2) Base_Mod
(2) Pin_303arrow
(2) insert_washer
(1) insert_303arrow_rev3 (unless you are not using the factory arrow insert, then 2)
(4) T_Nut-M3

Misc Materials and Tools:

Screwdrivers (or whatever fits the screws you select)
Pliers (or whatever to hold...things)
Sandpaper (320grit+/-)
Exact-o style knife (for general cleanup)
CA glue (for gluing insert to shaft)
Bamboo skewer, large (optional but very helpful)
Masking/Painter's tape (for cutting carbon shaft)

Assembly:

This is where things get interesting....
Most of it is straightforward and rather self-explanatory, so I won't bore you with a step-by-step for the obvious bits.

Prep:
Cut the carbon shaft to length. Mine ended up being about 21.5", but yours may vary slightly, depending on how you measure, and what angle you want on the brace.
VERY IMPORTANT NOTE: Cutting carbon fiber is no joke. Do NOT try to cut it with a hacksaw (or any toothed-saw, in fact) or any sort of cutting pliers. You'll just rip up the fibers, destroy the shaft, and most likely end up with painful fibers in your body.
Instead, either do it the right way, which is with a high-speed abrasive cut-off saw and respirator, or the ghetto-fabulous way, like I did.
Take a pair of wire strippers (type as shown in photo), wrap some masking tape around the area where you want to cut, and grip lightly like you are going to cut the shaft, but DO NOT squeeze hard. Just put a little pressure on it, with the jaws on the largest notches you can fit around the shaft. Rotate the shaft between your fingers, cutting a groove. Try to keep it square. After quite a few turns, it will drop off and you'll have a clean cut. Smooth up the ends with sandpaper. Be careful around the dust. It's not toxic, but it will jack up your lungs if you inhale it, so don't. Carbon fiber will dull your strippers very quickly, so either use an old pair, or use the largest jaws, which you probably never use for wire anyway, right?
Use CA glue (super glue) or whatever you like to glue the printed insert into the cut end of the shaft. Give it time to cure. Make sure you've already 'threaded' the insert before you glue it in place. It's very hard to do afterwards without breaking it free.

Here are the tricky parts:

  • Use a lighter or small torch (like shown in one of the photos) to gently heat up one of the M3 screws. Hold it with pliers and use the hot screw to thermoform threads in all 4 of the T-Nuts. It's tricky if you've never done it before, but easy once you do a couple. You have to get the threads all the way through and back out without stopping, or they might stick. Otherwise, it's pretty simple.
  • Use the same method for the printed insert, only be sure to use the 8-32 screw, so the formed threads will be correct.
  • When you're ready to install the T-Nuts in the vertical slots, they won't stay in long enough for you to install the screws. I got around this buy sticking a pair of earplugs into the track below where I wanted the nuts to sit. Then I put in the nuts, rotated them, and let them fall onto the earplugs. This held the nuts in position until I could get the base block in place and the screws started.
  • Speaking of rotating the nuts...I found that a large bamboo skewer like you'd use on the barbecue (from the Dollar Store) with a bit of the tip cut off works wonders as a "custom T-nut positioning tool". Stick the nut in the track, rotate it in place, pull out the skewer. Done.
    Of course the lower brace is much easier, since you're not fighting gravity, but the skewer was still helpful there.
  • Once you have the brace assembly....assembled, lightly snug up the screws just to the point that you can still slide the base along both tracks will a little force. push the top one all the way to the top, then tighten it down. BE CAREFUL. These are plastic T-Nuts. If you torque them down like a gorilla, they will absolutely strip out. In fact, this may be a good case for just using real metal T-nuts, if you have any. I just wanted to make this project as printable as possible, more as an exercise, and because I'm impatient.
  • Once the top base is secured, slide the bottom towards you until the washers bottom out at both ends, and puts a little (I said little, don't yank it!) tension on the shaft. Snug down the bottom screws.

You're done! Enjoy your (hopefully) more stable CR-10(S).

This is my fifth and final attempt to make a nut for tripods that can be printed at super low resolution, super fast. It is designed with two relief cuts that let the plastic flex slightly to grip the threads while being tight enough to cut threads into the plastic the first time you screw it on. The top of the print is actually the bottom (the part that gets screwed in first) due to the slight taper. This nut is designed to work with any nozzle diameter from .2-.8! Also, you can use any plastic that you have on hand. Personally, I used PET-G and it takes right around 1 minute 30 seconds per part. Check out the "Print Settings" section to see the settings I use and let me know what you think!

Printer:

heavily modified Geeetech i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.4

Infill:

(doesn't matter)

My original 1/4" nut design had threads which meant that you needed a good resolution (I used a .2 nozzle with .1 layers) and cooling enabled. I recently started experimenting with threadless designs to speed up printing and make it more available for others to use. My first version was basically just a hole in a piece of nut-shaped plastic. After printing 3 different sized holes it was clear that either it was too tight and seized or loose enough to turn but easy to strip. The next idea was 6 tiny relief cuts. That solved the seizing problem but it was easy to strip. My final step was to reduce the reliefs from 6-2 and make them wider. This lets it flex but only in one direction. This way both sides hold firm.

title: Mk10 HotEnd Heat Block Insulator - mould for silicone

description.text:
Mould to make your own silicone insulator for mk10 hotends with heat blocks measuring 19x19x12.5 mm (Wanhao i3 etc.)

I was seeing a temperature drop of my hotend when the cooling fan was on maximum. Using this silicone insulator has completely solved the problem. It also helps the hotend heat up faster and maintain its temperature.

You will need:

Curing liquid silicone rubber ~ 15 g
4 m3 nuts and bolts if using the 2 part mould base
Vaseline for mould release if using 1 part mould base

You can use the 2 part or 1 part mould base.

If you use the 1 part be sure to apply a thin layer of vaseline or other mould release to help demoulding. I'd recommend applying vaseline to the insert too.

Enjoy!

description.text:
Super simple bracket for attaching a GoPro camera to a robot built using the Vex IQ system. Modern GoPro cameras have a very low latency video stream, so this is a quick and simple way of getting a FPV stream from a Vex robot!

I basically mashed a GoPro mount on a VEX 2x4 plate. I used the CAD files published by VEX directly so the fit is exact. It may be hard to print on an FDM printer, but give it a shot. I managed it. In service I use parts from a HP MJF printer or a Stratasys Polyjet printer.

You will probably need an M5 acorn nut to complete this. I just glue the nut into the bracket so I don't lose it.

This was originally published on the Autodesk 123D site (now defunct).

I have a lot of places that won't work for the way the mounting holes are aligned in the original so I flipped it.
The slot fits a dime instead of a penny so his grill looks noice ;-)

I created this wrench to allow me to focus the camera while mounted in a bed-mounted camera holder. I use a Lulzbot bed-mounted camera holder with my Octopi setup, following this write-up: https://core-electronics.com.au/projects/time-lapsing-in-octoprint-properly
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/javCgyEh1lW

title: X axis idler for FLSUN Cube 3D printer

description.text:
This is a new mount for the X axis idler (H wheel as referred in the documentation). It provides for X belt tension adjustment, and sets the idlerl at the same height as the X motor spindle. It butts up against the holders for the two X poles, which take the pressure from the X belt tension.
There is also a small bush to fit inside the H wheel to convert the 5mm hole down to M3 screw diameter.
The mount uses the supplied holder for the H wheel which slides horizontally in the grooves on the new mount. The captive nut is removed, and the bolt goes into the holder and through the 3mm hole in the mount with a couple of M3 nuts to tension the belt and lock it. It requires an extra M3 screw and nut to mount it through the hole in the acryiic slider.
Just updated so that no support should be needed for printing

Hi,

Many 3D printable bearings out there are simply too weak and have not more than a decorative value.
In this approach, I tried to improve that and made a modified version of my 6mm softair BB bearing(https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2781113).
This one has a outer diameter of 40mm and inner diameter of 15mm. It utilises 22 4,5mm steel balls, widely used in CO2 guns(cal .177). The overall design is adapted from automotive wheel bearings.

NOTE:
For some reason the stl files are only a 1/10 of the intended size. You should scale them up by 1000% in order to get the correct dimensions

description.text:
Gera Pump with mountable housing

Hey folks,

This is one of my first projects that I had to create while studying at the technical college.
The gear pump has a rotating and a driven axle (red), which are mounted in brass press bearings (white).
The housing cover and drive axle are sealed by two seals that I printed in the model with black flex filament.

After completion, I tested the printed pump, it is even pumped, however, far less than previously calculated.
This is probably due to the greater deviation than in a CNC machined, on the other hand also to leaks in the drive axle.
The pump is therefore rather intended as a model.

have fun cheers,

Steffen ;-)

The seals (frontplate and drive axle) were printed with black flex filament in 0.2mm and 100% infill, as they are very small and optimally durable for the model purpose.

description.text: This is my promotional bag

comments.text:
It's not an easy job .
I have to work hard the bitmap / jpeg / png, etc ... to get reduced to two, three or four colors.
Then I convert it to vector, or various vector (crazy). Then transformed to STL.

description.text:
this is a work in progress, things may change, ill let everyone know if and when that happens.

so the idea is that when your printing with a full spool on a lazy susan its got quite a bit of inertia so it wants to keep spinning and throwing off filament, this is bad, very bad!

what im trying to do is as the extruder stops pulling filament, the tension on the arm relaxes and engages the stop on the rotor of the platter, that stops the platter revolving until the extruder starts pulling filament again and releases the arm from the rotor.

the little upstand on the base is to retain a spring that pushes the arm into the platter so it engages.

if you see anything that needs work let me know.

description.text:
There are others out there, this is what I came up with.

This lets you hang your filament spools from a 1 3/16" (30 mm) closet rod.

The lip on the end is 54mm, works great with my 1 kg rolls of Monoprice filament that I've been using.

Update (2018-02-06):
But mikepf, you say, what if they start to sag?

Then you get another 30 mm closet rod and run it through the middle of the spools, then you print out two of the newly uploaded closet rod hanger and use the hangers to hold it up and prevent the sagging. You'll need to remove the rod to change out spools, but this works out nicely if you just feed from the hanging spools to your printer.

title: 2020 Mountable Mechanical Filament Sensor with Bowden Connector

description.text:
This uses a mechanical endstop to act as a filament sensor. I took one already found on Thingiverse, added points to mount it to a 2020 extrusion and a bowden PC4-M6 mounting point as that's what I am using. Filament passes through this and when it triggers as empty, can send a signal to the printer for a filament change.

Bowden Fitting: http://a.co/iI2eXjH
EndStop: http://a.co/794m5yn

Connecting to Raspberry PI:

  • Voltage to PIN 1
  • Ground to PIN 6
  • Signal to PIN 7

In OctoPi, I use the Filament Sensor Reloaded plugin. Set it to Pin 7 with Normally Open and a 250 debounce and you should be good to go!

description.text:
PLEASE READ THE DESCRIPTION , cose isn't a simple print.

this is a modular cover studied to make safer and more useful our 3d printer power suppplies.
this cover is for any power supply with dimensions of: 190x11x50mm (actual real dimensions 198.50x110.50x50mm) this is a standard form factor so it is suitable for many power supplies.

MODELS:
there are actually 2 models:

  • standard
  • tush support

TYPES
each model has 3 types:

  • 1 - with iec plug +fuse and switch.
  • 2 - with iec plug +fuse
  • 3 - general purpose, modify as u wish

u can choose each type by their names, and also each type as a cover with is number.

COVERS
already made covers:

  • with one xt60 hole mount
  • with 2 xt60 hole mount
  • with tw0 8mm holes suitable for a female dc jack 5.5 2.1

ADDONS
each addons work with any models, and has more than one position so is up to u wich and how to use.

  • table/ wall mount feets
  • raspberry pi case
  • handle for transport (coming)

TOOLS NEEDED:
join front and back: #2 3Mx20mm bolts and nuts
cover 1-2 : 4# 3Mx12mm bolts and nuts
cover3 : 6# 3Mx12mm bolts and nuts
tush : #4 3Mx10mm bolts ,4# 608zz bearings
mount feets : #2 m3x 35-40mm bolts and nuts

PARTS TO PRINT:

  • one front
  • one back and the cover (caarfully choose yours)
  • any addons u want

each stl is already positioned for the best print with few supports

ENDER 2 users if u are not confortable with connectors and plugs u can just print the back version 3 and the cover 3 for ender 2 printer

I'm here for any modds or additions, hope to see few makes and have a feedback,
in the file list there is a fusion360 file to make the covers u need :)

NOTICE:
I've discovered that there are few tipes of iec plug that have the holes a bit shifted, in case appens just, drill a bit a new hole and force the screw, sorry for the little inconvenience but discovered few days ago when I got 2 new plugs..
anyway I have adapted the holes for the most common one, looking on aliexpress

MESSAGE:
if u like my work any support is appreciated, also just uploading the make of this thing will incite me to continue sharing my works :)

title: Reduced Binding Y bearing Block for Zaribo & Haribo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my original design for a bearing block that contains the bearing in X, Y, Z, but allows free rotation about the Z axis. This allows you to install your Y axis smooth rods and bearings with minimum binding. There is a cap that screws down over the bearing, which can be left loose enough to allow the Z axis rotation to continue or can be clamped down harder to freeze the bearing in position.

There are two included versions: one for 15mm OD bearings such as LM8UU and one for 16mm diameter bearings such as the blue PBC Linear Teflon bushings I am using on my Zaribo.

Each bearing block consists of two parts - the "holder" and the "cap". Eash assembly will require six (6) M3 square nuts, four (4) M3x16 or M3x18 screws to hold the cap onto the holder, and two (2) M3 screws to hold the holder to the bed carriage. If you are using a Prusa carriage, which is 6mm thick, these two mounting screws should be M3x10 or M3x12. If your bed carrier is 3mm thick, go with M3x8 or M3x10.

NOTE: The design intent of this block can be used for any printer, but the specifics of the geometry make this particular one suited to the Zaribo and Haribo. FYI, The two mounting screws are spaced 20mm apart.

Video: https://youtu.be/nvczhgm9Ipk

description.text:
A reverse Bowden relieves the the issue of layering artifacts caused by extrusions and retractions pulling on your filament spool. Even with an extremely fluid spool holder there is still some force that is exerted onto the extruder assembly causing small imperfections in your layer heights. Using this will move those actions outside of the extruder in the area between the tube end and the spool. With the constant pressure of the tube you will get far less layering artifacts and more consistent prints.

You'll also need to purchase this kit from amazon or if you have part lying around it should fit as well. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01F1XTRGI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

You only need a couple of feet of ptfe tube but I purchased this just to be safe and I have plenty of excess tube and the fittings are of really good quality.

title: Current Pickup and Spring Generator for Gauge G (IIm) and Gauge 1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Current Pickup and Spring Generator for Model Trains Gauge G (IIm) and Gauge 1.

I am now measuring different locomotives and wagons to develop fixing plates for the spring house box.

Please see also the *.scad files, I added a lot of comments and tips.

Version 2 released.
Enhancements for mounting options.

Version 2.1 released 2018/02/15
In CurrentPickup.scad more design options.
In StackedBladesSpring.scad much more mounting options.
Most advantage: size reduction of the spring box.

Version 3 released

Central mounting of the spring possible. Much size reduction. Easier installation.
See pictures 1, 2 and 3

Version 3.1 released (2018/03/06)
Changes: Source code decorated with much more comments.
Minor change in horizontal wing size (~ 1mm).

Don't mount the pickup far away before the front wheels or behind the back wheels. In narrow curves the pickup loses contact to the rail(s).

Add some ballast to the coach or locomotive. One spring has ~ 30 g (~ 0,29 N) tension. But you have 2 of them.

Note: If you use switches or crossings you have to install 2 pickups on each side with a minimum distance of 6 cm.

Some improvement for the driven wheels: Mount a rubber band 70mm x 5mm

description.text:
We are now on version 1.5 of the Stirring Support. It kind of looked like a starship from a certain famous TV show, so I decided to take it to the next generation :) Yes, this is a friendly homage to the great Star Trek franchise. Print long and prosper.

It's actually for supporting your wash vessels when you are using a magnetic mixer.
I use a magnetic stirrer to wash my Moonray prints. To support larger containers, I designed this support platform.
https://youtu.be/J8-p2sVBmrw

I have not tested this print on any SLA printer. Please let me know how it works for you. I tried to design it within Sprintray's design guidelines for overhangs and bridging.

Changelog:
1.5s - Hollowed out the arms and added lateral drain holes for all that uncured resin to drain. It would be more ideal to place them at the top, but then anything you spill on that platform gets trapped inside the arms forever.
1.4s Beefed up the arms to compensate for SLA. Also hollowed out the fuselage a bit to conserve resin.
1.4 Added larger "nacelle" platforms to land your vessels more easily. And Trekk'd it up. Version 1.4 is still the most current version optimized for FDM. It might work for your SLA printer as well.

1.3b Fixed small holes with Meshmixer. Should be watertight now.
1.3 Added upper bevels. Enlarged the main base.
1.2 Beefed up some of the arms. Added a filet (reverse bevel) the bottoms to facilitate removal from the print bed.

Washing idea from Dr. Baron Grutter.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EwRfQZT33wk&list=PLZ5lds9W8W8qasFFHUZfDoCqp89G0jlkh

Printer:

Prusa i3 Mark 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm layers

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For both SLA and FDM versions, print with the central fuselage on the bed. Not the nacelles.

For FDM, I would recommend simple PLA with cooling after the 1st layer. On my prusa i3 mk2, I printed with 0.20mm layers and 40mm/s print speed with just a few minor overhang sags where no one can see.

For Moonray, 100 micron layers is fine. The polygon count is too low to benefit from 50 let alone 20 micron layers. Opaque resins like the gray will probably be best. Make sure you post cure at least 30 minutes.

I sliced off the bottom to create a flat side to allow printing of the ring vertically. I am going to print with rafts and supports so we'll see how it goes.

description.header: Possible sources for parts (as of March 2013)
description.text:
• Laser cut aluminum parts: 247 Tailorsteel
  • Keyboard and hinges: used ThinkPad X4x
  • Screws: used ThinkPads X4x and T4x
  • Glue for aluminum: Weicon RK-1500 construction glue available at Modulor as item #175500
  • Neodymium magnets: eBay
  • Feet: Modulor item #303602 (bumper, self-adhesive elastic spacer transparent, h = 1.9 mm, d = 6.4 mm)
  • 3 mm flat aluminum profile: 10 x 3 mm AlMgSi0.5 profile available at alu-verkauf.de.
  • 1 mm flat aluminum profile: alu-verkauf.de 1 mm AlMg3 plate
  • L-shaped aluminum profile: alu-verkauf.de 10 x 10 x 2 mm AlMgSi0.5 profile
  • Distance plate: Modulor item #548634 (Forex Classic PVC foam board, 3.0 x 250 x 500 mm, black)
  • Wooden bezel: Modulor items #267321 and #267303 (right-angled pear tree wood moulding strip, 2.0 x 5.0 mm and 2.0 x 2.0 mm)
  • Wood paint: Modulor
  • Light pipe: Modulor item #133420 (Acrylic glass GS transparent, 2.00 x 115 x 240 mm)
  • Tape: Modulor item #155826S (Tesa fabric adhesive tape, 38 mm wide, black)
  • Foam rubber: Modulor item #317464L (Foam rubber sealing strip, self-adhesive 2 x 10 mm, black)
  • Micro USB receptacle: Amphenol MUSB-K152-30 available at element14 with order code #523-MUSB-K152-30
  • RGB LED: element14 order code #2354239 (Kingbright KAF-5060PBESEEVGC)
  • Slider: Song Huei SL-20V sliding potentiometer available on request at F.K. Kobler Industrievertretungen

• Grinder / File for creating shallow channels in aluminum and distance plate, for accommodating FCC.
  • Saw and drills for preparing distance plate and wooden bezel.
  • Drill for M2 core holes in aluminum.
  • Tap for M2 threads in aluminum.
  • Screw driver for M2 Phillips screws.

• Model of ThinkPad X4x keyboard & TrackPoint, available on GrabCAD.
  • Tablet model, available in raw form on GrabCAD. For rendering, materials have been added, etc.

description.text:
Want your feeder stepper outside of your UM2? Print this bracket. It is a noise dampening. It rotates the feeder so that the knurled side of the filament does not rub against the bowden tubes side.

Please not that you filament reel cannot be bigger than your typical 1KG reel. The new position of the feeder stepper blocks a part of the reel holder.

Update: use the v3 bracket, it is stronger. The v2 bracket will sag over time when printing. Also the v3 bracket needs no support while printing.

Before printing. After you removed build-in support. Assembly

Disassemble feeder and feeder stepper from the Ultimaker 2. That means disconnecting the feeder stepper from the electronics board and re-routing the wires.

Mount bracket on original feeder stepper holes using 4 (new) pieces of M3x16 (or larger) bolt with captive nuts.

Mount feeder stepper and feeder on bracket. Bracket was designed to use the iroberti_feeder with Meduzas belt feeder. But original feeder also fits.

author: Reeses88

description.text:
So I wanted to write about my journey from stock Anet A8 to Skynet then finally to Marlin. In my things you will see bits of code posted for setting up the print heads for the printer. This guide is more about converting from one firmware to another. This applies to RAMPS converted units only. I have not tried Marlin on a stock Anet A8 board, for that I use Skynet3d from https://github.com/thijsk/Skynet3d

I have included the files for the 18mm Sensor Carriage with chain from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2766701

For how to wire a RAMPS board see https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2784817

Marlin can be found at http://marlinfw.org See that site for detailed instructions, information and guides.

OK on to the guide!

This is to achieve 3 goals for me:

  • A universal firmware with large community support
  • Advanced features and controls
  • Future proofing and improvements to come

For me Marlin meets these goals. I already posted a link to the firmware page but you will also need a few more things.

  • Arduino IDE on your computer from https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/Software
  • I like to use Notepadd++ for quick edits https://notepad-plus-plus.org/
  • a USB cable to attach your Arduino to your PC
  • RAMPS 1.4 or 1.5 board http://reprap.org/wiki/RAMPS_1.4
  • Arduino MEGA 2560 or clone https://www.arduino.cc/en/Main/ArduinoBoardMega2560?setlang=en

Once you have these things and have wired your printer up to the RAMPS board you need some firmware to control things. First step is to download Marlin from the website above. Extract the folder and install the Arduino IDE.

Inside the downloaded folder for Marlin you will find \Marlin-1.1.x\Marlin\example_configurations\Anet\A8. In that folder is two files Configuration.h and Configuration_adv.h. Copy these files into \Marlin-1.1.x\Marlin replacing what is there. This is the basic configuration for the Anet A8 and gets you started.

Now if you really want to download this thing in inside is my Configuration.h for my Anet A8 with my carriage from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2766701 and an 18mm inductive sensor with bilinear bed leveling. Just like above copy these files into \Marlin-1.1.x\Marlin overwrite what's there. Then you can just tweak them to meet your needs. This might be the easiest route.

Open the Arduino IDE and browse to your downloaded Marlin files. Inside \Marlin-1.1.x\Marlin you will find Marlin.INO. This is the file you need to load into the Arduino IDE.

Inside the Arduino IDE you will see tabs across the top. Select the tab "Configuration.h" and start reading. There's lots of comments to help you setup and understand what each line does but there are a few we will need to concentrate on.

The sample configurations assume a bone stock Anet A8 with stock carriage and all. You can just run with those if that is what you have.

First thing to change is the serial baudrate. This is set with the line '#define BAUDRATE 115200' This is the stock setting for an Anet A8 and works just fine. If you encounter issues with dropped communication when printing consider slowing it down a little. '#define BAUDRATE 57600' is the next slowest for example.

Next thing to set is your motherboard. In the tab "Boards.h" you will find a list of the boards and their codes. I use '#define MOTHERBOARD BOARD_RAMPS_14_EEB' because I have RAMPS 1.5 with Extruder, Extruder, Build plate heater connections. These corospond to the screw terminals marked D10, D9, D8 on the RAMPS board. So what we have set here is:

  • RAMPS Motherboard
  • D10 is extruder 0
  • D9 is extruder 1
  • D8 is heated bed

Now with this setting the firmware automatically moves the cooling fan PWM output to the SERVO section on the RAMPS board. The set of 3 servo pins furthest from the RAMPS power connector are what is used but be aware these pins are not meant to handle power. You will need to use a MOSFET between them and 12v to power the fans. I found inexpensive Arduino compatable MOSFETs on Amazon for a few dollars.

This must be set to '#define BOARD_RAMPS_14_EFB' if you have a single extruder. This assigns the outputs to:

  • RAMPS Motherboard
  • D10 is extruder 0
  • D9 is fcooling fans
  • D8 is heated bed

Next comes the '#define CUSTOM_MACHINE_NAME "Your Name Here" ' line. This is just the name reported over serial and displayed in the printer ready message on the LCD screen. It can be set to about anything.

The next line sets the number of extruders. This goes with the motherboard setting above. '#define EXTRUDERS 2' if you have 2, '#define EXTRUDERS 1' for one, so on.

Next is the setting for filiment size. This is how the machine calculates how much to feed. Set it to 1.75 if that is what you are using, it is pretty much the standard though there are other sizes. '#define DEFAULT_NOMINAL_FILAMENT_DIA 1.75' for 1.75.

A little further down is the next one to look at. If you have more than one extruder you need to remove the //'s in front of both lines and set your offset. If single extruder leave this commented out. '#define HOTEND_OFFSET_X {0.0, 35.00}' and '#define HOTEND_OFFSET_Y {0.0, 0.00}' is the setting for my dual extruder heads for example.

There's a large block of text talking about thermal sensors. We might need to change this especially if you have dual extuders. '#define TEMP_SENSOR_0 5' is for extruder 0 for example and tells the firmware you have a 100K thermistor type sensor. This is the most common type. I have the settings below set for my dual extruder carriage.

  • '#define TEMP_SENSOR_0 5'
  • '#define TEMP_SENSOR_1 5'
  • '#define TEMP_SENSOR_2 - 4 are set to 0'
  • '#define TEMP_SENSOR_BED 5'

I do not mess with the PID and thermal runaway settings. They seem fine.

Next section is endstop inverting. These all should be set to true.

  • '#define X_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING true'
  • '#define Y_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING true'
  • '#define Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING true'
  • '#define X_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING true'
  • '#define Y_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING true'
  • '#define Z_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING true'
  • '#define Z_MIN_PROBE_ENDSTOP_INVERTING true'

Next we have Distict E Factors. This lets you setup your dual extruders with differnt feed speeds. Uncomment the line '#define DISTINCT_E_FACTORS' to enable this if needed. I run two identical extruders so I left it commented out.

Following is the default axis steps per unit. The unit here is MM. This is an initial setting. I use LV8729 drivers on 1/32 microstepping. This means the following must be set here.

  • '#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {200, 200, 800, 200}'

If you are using 1/16th stepping you would set:

  • '#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {100, 100, 400, 100}'

Skipping ahead we come to the Z Probe Options. This is where you setup the probe for auto level.

The line '#define Z_MIN_PROBE_USES_Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_PIN' means the probe is connected to the same pins as the min Z switch was.

You can comment that line out and set the line below it '#define Z_MIN_PROBE_ENDSTOP xx' where XX is the Arduino pin number for where the probe signal goes.

Probe type is reffering to the mounting. All my heads use a fixed probe so set

  • '#define FIX_MOUNTED_PROBE'

Down from there is the settings for the offsets. Using my Front Sensor Carriage from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2766701 you would set:

  • '#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 17'
  • '#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -23'
  • '#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -2.1'

The last line is the difference in height between the extruder nozzle and the probe trigger point. We will come back to that.

I like to uncomment and turn on '#define MULTIPLE_PROBING 2' to set it to probe each point twice. This is to make sure that it has an accurate reading.

Next few lines to tweak are the Z clearances. This is what tells the machine to lift up between probe points. I like to turn this on so I always clears.

  • '#define Z_CLEARANCE_DEPLOY_PROBE 10 // Z Clearance for Deploy/Stow '
  • '#define Z_CLEARANCE_BETWEEN_PROBES 5 // Z Clearance between probe points'

This means it will lift 10mm from the bed when it starts and stops probing and between each point it will lift 5mm before moving.

Down from there is the machine settings and motor inverting settings. This depends on how you wired it and the motor drives used. Mine is all backwards so I had to change these settings to what you see below. Keep in mind you might not have to.

  • '#define INVERT_X_DIR true'
  • '#define INVERT_Y_DIR true'
  • '#define INVERT_Z_DIR false'
  • '#define INVERT_E0_DIR false'
  • '#define INVERT_E1_DIR true'

The reason one is inverted and the other not is because of how I mounted them. Again this setting depends on many things and should be checked by carefully moving the printer once the firmware is flashed.

Down from there is the settings for the bed size.

  • '#define X_BED_SIZE 220'
  • '#define Y_BED_SIZE 220'

Then the travel limits. These are also known as Home Offsets and can be changed via terminal later. For my Carriage its:

  • '#define X_MAX_POS 240'
  • '#define X_MIN_POS -10'
  • '#define Y_MAX_POS 225'
  • '#define Y_MIN_POS -13'
  • '#define Z_MAX_POS 230'
  • '#define Z_MIN_POS 0'
    These are also used for the software endstops.

Next we come to the Bed Leveling section. This is where you choose how and where to probe. I like to use Bilinear for it gives excellent results and is easy to run. You must add G29 to the start Gcode of your prints after it homes.

Uncomment the line '#define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_BILINEAR' to enable or choose what you think will be best for you.

You can choose how many points it probes with the settings

  • ' #define GRID_MAX_POINTS_X 4'
  • ' #define GRID_MAX_POINTS_Y GRID_MAX_POINTS_X'

This gives 4x4 or 16 probe points. Less is faster more is more precise. More than 7 though can cause performance and memory issues.

Once you choose one you must set where the probe can reach. For my front probe carriages on an Anet A8 it's

  • '#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 30'
  • '#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200'
  • '#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 190'
  • '#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20'

As a part of this check and be sure that '#define Z_SAFE_HOMING' is enabled and not commented out. By default in the Marlin config for the Anet A8 it should be enabled.

Moving on to the Additional Settings section we come to Preheat Constants. Set your Preheat settings here. I like to run 50c on the bed and 200c on the extruders. It you have more than one extruder you must have more than one setting here like below.

Extruder 0:

  • '#define PREHEAT_1_TEMP_HOTEND 200'
  • '#define PREHEAT_1_TEMP_BED 50'
  • '#define PREHEAT_1_FAN_SPEED 0 // Value from 0 to 255'

Extruder 1:

  • '#define PREHEAT_2_TEMP_HOTEND 200'
  • '#define PREHEAT_2_TEMP_BED 50'
  • '#define PREHEAT_2_FAN_SPEED 0 // Value from 0 to 255'

Now to LCD and SD support. This is where you setup your LCD controller. I like to use the RAMPS compatible RepRapDiscount FULL GRAPHIC Smart Controller. This is also known as the 12864 LCD. A common issue with these is the knob goes the wrong direction. You change it with the line '#define REVERSE_ENCODER_DIRECTION' by uncommenting it.

From the list below that line uncomment the one that matches your controller. Using the same example that is '#define REPRAP_DISCOUNT_FULL_GRAPHIC_SMART_CONTROLLER'

That should be enough to get you going!

Now to compile. From the TOOLS menu in the Arduino IDE select your board. In this case it's "Arduino/Genduino MEGA or MEGA 2560". Then select your COM port the board is connected to.

Click on the checkmark button at the top of the screen and the program will compile. This will take a few minutes and if there's any issues it will tell you what they are in orange print in the black bar at the bottom of the screen. If all is well it will say "Done Compiling" and give you a summary of the memory usage.

With it compiled it's time to upload. Hit the -> right arrow looking icon at the top with your board plugged in to USB and it will compile then upload. Once again you will get "Upload Complete" should it all work out fine and now it's programmed.

From here you need to verify everything is moving in the right directions. Move your axis slowly to be sure. Once all tests pass try warming it up. Make sure the temperature probes are reporting right and everything else is working.

Assuming you use a probe to do Autoleveling you will need to set the Z offset. Here's the easy route I found.

  • Home all axis with G28
  • Set the offset to 0 to start with M851 Z0 then send M500 and load with M501
  • Move to the middle of the bed with G1 X110 Y110
  • Turn off software endstops. This means your machine could potentially crash into the bed so be careful, M211 S0
  • Place a bit of paper on the bed under the nozzle and preheat the machine. Bring it up to operating temperature and be careful! Don't get burned.
  • Lower the Z slowly until that bit of paper is lightly pinched between the bed and nozzle.
  • Send command M114 to get the current position. You will see something like Recv: X:110.00 Y:110.00 Z:2.10 E:0.00 Count X:26000 Y:22000 Z:1680
  • From that line take the Z position and add a - to the front for Z-2.1 in this example
  • Set the offset with M851 Z-2.1 be sure to use your offset!
  • BE SURE TO ENABLE SOFTWARE ENDSTOPS with M211 S1
  • Save the setting with M500
  • You can run a quick autolevel with G29 to make sure it all works.

In your slicer be sure to add the line G29 ;Autolevel to the start gcode under the line with G28 in it. This levels the printer at the start of each print. Great if your machines moves around like mine. I take it place to place.

That should be it, you now have auto leveling Marlin powered Anet A8. There's a lot I glossed over but you can learn more from these links where I sourced this guide from.

  • http://marlinfw.org/
  • https://3dprint.wiki/reprap/anet/a8/improvement/autobedleveling
  • http://marlinfw.org/docs/gcode/M851.html
  • http://marlinfw.org/docs/gcode/M206.html
  • http://marlinfw.org/docs/gcode/M092.html
  • http://marlinfw.org/docs/gcode/M218.html
  • http://marlinfw.org/docs/gcode/M114.html
  • https://github.com/MarlinFirmware/Marlin/wiki/EEPROM
  • https://www.arduino.cc/
  • http://reprap.org/wiki/RAMPS_1.4
  • http://www.reprap.org/mediawiki/images/0/06/RAMPS_dossier.pdf
  • http://www.reprap.org/

And of course the Thingiverse community!

Thank you! Like, share it with those who can benefit, yell at me in the comments if I got it wrong and enjoy!

description.text:
A hexaflexagonal strip featuring triangles with a side length of 30mm.

It is intended to be a design experiment, using flexible TPU filament. Please rotate as necessary to fit the strip on the printer bed. Once it is printed, one should fold it in a way that allows for the same letters (A or B or C) to show up on one side. Then, super-glue the two triangles with no letters for a hexaflexagon.

Indeed, paper, plus a glue stick, is the best way to make a hexaflexagon for classroom use. However, a flexible TPU model is also fun!

title: S3 Pattycake FPV Hovercraft / Tiny Whoov

description.text:
Convert your quadcopter into a hovercraft - introducing the S3 Pattycake FPV Hovercraft!

Features:

  • prints in two parts, no support needed
  • parts snap together
  • snap-in camera mount
  • snap-in motor mounts
  • snap-in flight control board mount
  • slide-in battery mount
  • "all-up" weight of less than 38 grams with all components, battery!
  • NO glue required!
  • NO programming required!
  • NO wire extensions or additional soldering required!

Required: one of several common quadcopters, like the blade inductrix, blade inductrix FPV, or any tiny whoop variation.

Instructions:

  • move your flight controller, FPV camera, motors and propellers to the new S3 Pattycake frame. Be sure front motors stay in front (main body), rear motors stay in rear motor mounts.
  • note: press in motors from the underside and rear of motor mounts. They will not push all the way through the mount, they should sit just below the motor mount's top/front surface under a small lip.
  • when plugging in your motors, plug front-left motor into back-left port, back-left motor into front-left port, and same on the right side... this will keep your S3 Pattycake from spinning out of control

Piloting:

  • use your throttle/yaw stick for everything!

Enjoy :P

title: Simple & Strong 1/4"-20 Winged Camera & Tripod Screw

description.text:
Having tried a few 3D printed 1/4"-20 screws, I found that they are generally quite weak.
This is because usually they are printed upwards, which means the layers are arranged in a way where it's easy to break the screws with twisting or pulling force. In other words, not ideal.

This simple design is made to be printed on its side so that the layer structure is aligned in a way where it can deal with twisting and pulling forces. Due to this, it is massively stronger than the screws printed in an upwards position.

Includes 3 different lengths of thread: 7mm, 10mm & 15mm.
If you require any other lengths or specific variants, feel free to make a request in the comments.

This Processing sketch generates a *.scad file containing a screw nut module that can be used in OpenScad. Just enter the parameters in the sketch file and hit run to get your screw in seconds.  
The main advantage of this method before using one of the advanced screw libraries is, that the generated file renders within seconds, while the libraries take an eternity to render a screw because they use boolean math to join a large number of polyhedrons and prims together to form the screw. This script only generates one geometry with no need for boolean hours of boolean math.

You need Processing for this, get it at processing.org.  
Internally the script creates one large polyhedron with all the faces that make the screw nut. If you want flat ends just cut them off with a large cube. The polyhedron is then wrapped in a module named "screw". Open the test.scad to see how to use the module.  
If you want to change the screw diameter, size or whatever, just rerun the script with different parameters.

I don't like drill stop designs where a screw touches the drill, as they tend to skew on the drill, especially on drills with thin blades, like wood drills. With this design, the whole inner surface of the drill stop holds the drill.

To assembly it, you need an M3 washer, M3 nut and M3 screw, 12mm length (it may be a little bit shorter for smaller drill diameters). The nut should be a very tight fit to prevent turning.

A tip for an easy insertion of the nut:

  • insert a long M3 screw (at least 20mm) through the screw hole
  • put the nut on this screw and screw it till the nut is in the position
  • gently unscrew the long screw leaving the nut in the place
  • put the washer and the final screw

This is a replacement lens for those stake garden solar lights sold at stores like Walmart. I keep having problems with the lenses clouding up and going orange after just a few months and end up having more of the heads and stakes than usable lenses.

You'll need to use a transparent or translucent filament to get a clear lens, and may have to experiment with infill density to get the desired transparency of the lens. The picture shown of a complete garden light is with the infill set to 100%.

You may also have to adjust the diameter of the base shaft to fit the stakes you have as the diameter tends to vary a bit between production runs.

description.text:
A simple Snap-fit case for a raspberry pi 3.

Originally designed By Adrien on grabcad. then edited by me.

Link to Orginal file:
https://grabcad.com/library/raspberry-pi-case-model-b-2-3-1

Customized MPCNC designed by Alted, miniXT - small working area & extra tall. I need a machine that will be able to print and laser engrave and will fit my work table. Also, the storage is an issue so I wanted it to be hoisted under the ceiling. All the electronics is mounted on the middle horizontal tube or tubes.
The support tubes are 1/2" electrical conduit (18mm OD)
Hardware is standard for the original MPCNC, 6-32 screws and nuts or small wood screws (mainly for some clamps).

Parts:
midd stiff ...... rev.B: These have to be installed while assembling the frame. They slide on the corner tubes.

midd stiff ......: Can be added to a current frame. Each part consist of two halves - inner & outer. Please note that these has not been tested, I use the permanent version above.

corner lock block: to square frame easily. Mark centers of the corner tubes and drill the holes in your baseplate. Screw puck in each and slide the tubes over. They'll not move while screwing the "Flex_Foot_bottom" to your platform and keep the frame square (if measured and marked correctly :-))

LCD face, bottom, bracket, reset button: housing for 12864 screen

power block top, bottom: housing for AC wall power splitter (https://frys.com/product/8449228?site=sr:SEARCH:MAIN_RSLT_PG). Needs some soldering, added a wall switch & PC power plug connector. 3 outlet always on, 3 outlets switchable on/off

power supply bracket: mount for 30A power supply but I believe the mounting holes are the same for 20A as well

ramps box top, bottom, reset button, resset button housing: oversize housing for ramps 1.4 with Mega board. Big openings for cable management, bottom hole for rocker switch (to manage 12V input to laser engraver etc.)

speed control mount: mount for Harbor Freight Router Speed Control (https://www.harborfreight.com/router-speed-control-43060.html)

surface pro bracket, holder: mount for my MS Surface Pro (1st gen) allows to have the keyboard connected. Holder will keep it close while not using.

z axis chain guard: the machine has extended z axis travel and the chain is pretty long - this part will let the chain to slide over and not interfere with the center assembly.

Miscellaneous clamps, endstop mounts etc.

Please feel free to ask if anything is unclear or missing or so.

My other attachments, chain mods and other will be published in a different Thingiverse thing. Will post a link here when ready.

description.text:
I remade these from easy carts upgrade by SgaboLab. I added places for nuts to be added to make it easier to get the right tension on the pulleys and the wheels separately. I added some height from his design to account for the washer I had to use to get the pulleys to line up on my machine, (about 1.4mm). in order to use the pulleys you will need longer M5 bolts for on corner on each of the carriages . I got 50mm bolts and its a close fit, so if you can find 60mm you will have more breathing room.

SgaboLabs thingy:https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2574935

pulleys I got - 1 of these:https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01H3F8LUU/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s03?ie=UTF8&psc=1

and 2 of these: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01H3DNKYY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s03?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I had bearing spacers from a wheel kit I had for an older machine I had. Aliexpress might be a good source for those.

Notes:

I made these so they could sit as they are imported and print with no supports. so no digging in the holes for stuck plastic bits! these do not have a lot of pressure on them, so its really your choice as to what infill amount you want. I would do at least 20% if your machine will see a ton of use you may want to print them solid for long life.

with a 0.4 nozzle I did 2 perimeters, with 6 top and bottom layers in PETG

If the top of your print isn't smooth and interferes with the bearing spacer put a piece of 200grit or close sand paper on a flat surface and slide the top on it rotating often until it smooth enough for your liking. jusdon't do you drastically change the height of the part.

use a cap screw, the ones with a hex key hole in the top, put the nut in and then thread the screw through it, put a nut and washer on the opposite side and tighten it down. this will press the nut in so it won't come out easily. then just take off the nut/washer and remove the screw, the nut should be pressed in tight and ready for use.
I used Fusion360 and SgaboLab's design as a model for what height to start with, then adjusted it for the washers I used to get height correct with the pulleys I used.
