title: Monoprice Select Mini shipping spacer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a ridiculously simple little thing that makes my life easier. My Monoprice Select Mini printer is great, and it's just small enough to be "portable". I find the easiest way to transport it is in the original box with the foam inserts. Only thing is - it's designed for a very specific Z height, too high or too low and it won't fit right in the foam insert. What to do? Originally I just winged it, but that doesn't work well. Then I took measurements with my calipers and checked against that... but finally I got lazy and printed this really simple little thing. The key dimension is 24mm - the gap between the print bed and the Z arm, not the print head. You could print out this thing at 24mm - or absolutely anything else that you wanted - just scale it to 24mm. When you're ready to shut down and pack up your printer, put the thing on the print bed and manually lower the Z arm until it's just clear of the part, and boom, you're ready to go. You can shut down the printer and put it in the shipping box with no problems.

It really is simple to the point of being pointless, but hopefully at least someone finds it helpful. I could post the SketchUp source file, but seriously - it's a 24mm long cylinder 10mm in diameter. That's it.

title: Ikea LOTS mirror bed bracket for CR-10 with cable strain relief
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Brackets for the CR-10 that conveniently fit Ikea LOTS mirrors (http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/39151700/) to the bed, so you can easily swap mirrors out, remove them from the bed (for cleaning, removing a print, or if you have different mirrors with different adhesion sollutions (glue, tape, hairspray, PEI...) etc) and without needing the clips, which may bend the mirror down when the aluminum bed is warped underneath.

After finding out the hard way that the stock glass plate that comes with the printer is rubbish (bent to hell and back), i decided to buy the cheap Ikea mirrors that people have been using. They are 300 by 300 mm, so they fit the CR-10 bed. But since they are 10 mm smaller than the actual bed, that meant the brackets i originally designed for use with the stock glass plate (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2525325), wouldn't work with the mirrors anymore. So i had to alter them, so they would fit the mirrors between them.

There is a strain relief for the cable in the left back corner. Parts are best printed in ABS, 0.2mm layer height, with supports. Be careful removing the supports so you don't snap the top part off. I printed it with only 1 wall, but 100% infill diagonal lines. I felt it made the top part sturdier that way, since the infill lines covered more surface.

If the plastic part from the Z stepper motor is sticking out a bit, you may want to shave that a little. The bed brackets are as thin as they should be (thinner and they would not be sturdy enough) and should easily pass the frame without slamming into it. But the yellow Z stepper bracket stuck out a bit on my printer.

Ideally you'd print the regular corner bracket 3 times, but maybe you can get away with only the strain relief and one regular bracket in the diagonally opposing corner. The strain relief has four holes for zip ties. If the cap falls off, you can loop the zip tie from underneath around the top.

title: Bibo Glass Clamp with Optional Lip

description.text:
I broke one of my glass clamps the other day, Bibo said they would send me another, but the boat is pretty slow at getting here. So I created a program to make them. One of the things I found is the holes on the aluminum bed are not symmetrical. So settings on one side will not necessary fit correctly on the other side.

The default settings are what I used for mine. But most can be changed in case you want the fit to be different.

This will create both left and right one at a time.
I added a Lip feature that will hold the glass close to the bed so it wont lift for whatever reason. Seems to work really well I thought I might have to have some adjustment but I don't have any problem getting the glass in and out as needed to remove prints. This has been working great for me my Alum. bed will warp down for whatever reason and the glass will start rocking. This lip helps a lot with that problem. Before i would just bend the bed up again. That's how I broke the lip in the first place. I would advise not to make lip too big other wise if you have a problem and restart the printer and the nozzles stick to the bed your glass could break if the printer tries to home without heating the nozzles first.

I printed mine out of PLA 20% infill, top down with supports. I printed top down to make everything as accurate as possible. the Support is only for the recess for the screw. I found after a couple of prints the i have to tighten everything up. I have close to 100 prints on mine now and they are holding tight. no issues with PLA.

The clamp with the screw in should not wiggle much if at all. If it does you may need to adjust the Screw XY positions.

Other than that if your running the stock Bibo you probably wont have any other adjustments. Other than Lip or no Lip.

Also you can print the settings on top of the clamp. There are so many I cant really read mine printed but you can on the STL, in-case if you need the settings later. can also change the Version on the back side so you can track which is which. Either or both can be disabled if you don't want them.

i have included the NS(No Settings) version .STL which do not have the settings written on top or bottom of the clamps so it will print a little cleaner..

This is a Deckbox for the awesome deck building game "Star Realms". I've gotten addicted to the digital version, and just picked up the Colony Wars set of physical cards - and they needed protection.

This box will hold all of a starter/colony wars with extra room for a couple of dozen cards or so, especially if you leave out the instructions (and more if you use an alternate form of tracking Authority, and leave those cards behind).

Sand top of box to improve fit

The box and lid are purposely designed to fit very tightly; it holds a lot of cards, so to get the best fit and pass the "upside-down jiggle" test with the cards in there, the best method seems to be to print it super tight, then sand and test until the fit is just smooth enough to be easy to open, while still keeping it tight enough to do its job.

description.text:
Vast The Crystal Caverns designed by Patrick Leder, David Somerville.These 3D files are not intended to challenge their rights and has been done with their permission.

The dragon has been asleep for many long years. In that time, the cave under which it slumbered has changed greatly…Goblins and strange monsters have filled its gloomy depths and there are whispers that the cave itself has begun thinking, shifting, and growing evermore dangerous.

Still, stories of peril rarely overshadow the rumors of riches. And riches there may be… For where a dragon slumbers, there also lies a fiercely guarded treasure. Fortunately for the slumbering beast, malevolent crystals fill the cave’s rooms with spectral light, hiding the entrance to the immeasurable treasure trove. Many have given their lives to the search and over the years the rumors have faded to legend.

Tiles based on the Print and Play of this fabulous game.
Full detail about this game may be found here http://ledergames.com/vast/

description.text:
This is for the Monoprice mini delta. The cooling fan blows directly on the the back of the heatbed where the thermistor is and this is intended to plug the hole. There are two prototypes, one with ears for magnets to be attached under the bed and one with no magnets to fit under the bed. The magnetic version is a little too thick to fit under the bed like in the picture but it gets the idea across. I have not printed or tested the non-magnetic version.

Since this is near the actual part that heats up on the bed, be sure to use a high temperature material like ABS or preferably PETG. I originally tried to block the hole with kapton tape but the heat caused it to rip itself apart. Others have used a flash card taped to the inside of the printer. I also suggest using concentric supports for the lip with about 25-30% support density (the lip is small so a lot of support is needed).
Upper sheet of base drone

The SlightlyOdd Muzzle Brake works to redirect the Apollo's hurricane-like exhaust gasses backward, yet away from the user, thereby adding a little forward thrust to counteract the massive kick the weapon generates. The SlightlyOdd Muzzle Brake also adds more mass to your Apollo, which has the same effect! Say "goodnight" to uncomfortable, sleepless nights!

Don't like that this muzzle brake reduces velocity? Add the sleeve inside the brake to prevent pressure loss! Keep in mind the sleeve increases recoil!

description.text:
This is a little decorative thing I modeled to show what your extruder motor is doing. This one uses a small 6.2mm diameter magnet and sticks to the stepper using the magnet. It works great on a Prusa where the motor faces forward, and doesn't obstruct any other printer movements. I'm sure it would work on other printers, but I'm not sure which. I was inspired by this post from Prusa's website:

https://www.prusaprinters.org/visualize-extruder-motor-movements/

Keep in mind this print is very small when slicing and printing, and you will need to rotate it 90 degrees to print properly.

I just realized it also works great as a cool white board magnet, or magnet for any other surface!

title: Magnetic Glass Bed Clips - Wanhao D6 / Monoprice Ultimate
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are highly customizable bed clips for the Wanhao Duplicator 6 / Monoprice Maker Ultimate. The bottom piece bolts to the bottom of the bed using 3mmx6mm machine screws. The original screws are not long enough, so you'll need longer ones. How long depends on how you customize the part, but the default settings work very well with 3mmx8mm screws with the original cardboard washer.

EDIT 2/6/2018 IMPORTANT: Noticed an error in my config file, in the section that generates the magnet holder wall thickness. I failed to multiply the wall thickness by 2 resulting in a wall that is 1/2 the desired thickness. It is fixed in the current version of both the scad files and the STL files.

These solve the problem of holding down a glass print bed and thermal material while still clearing even the most bulky fan ducts, and also allow for easy removal. They are also self-aligning. They will work with either 2 corner or 4 corner placement.

Defaults in the config file are set for the 5/16" x 5/64" neodymium rare earth magnets from Harbor Freight. (Item number 67488). The uploaded STL files also use these settings. STL Files are set for a 9.5mm total bed thickness. This includes the stock metal build plate plus a .5mm thermal pad and a 3mm borosilicate glass sheet. The original build surface is NOT included. I removed that sheet before applying glass to my printer.

All three SCAD files are necessary to print a complete set. All customization should be done in the clips-config.scad file

Print settings don't matter too much. Lower layer heights will obviously produce a more precise fit for the magnets.

I am currently experiencing heat creep with the stock fan, and was looking for a dual fan setup, but I imagined the 40mm would be more commonly used for the heatsink. comments.text: This was more logic on my part I'd guess. I sort of figured that if they used the 30mm fan to cool the hotend AND part, then it would be sufficient to cool the hot end all on it's own. I was more personally more concerned with part cooling to improve bridging and whatnot. So far I've seen some noticeable improvements! I'll be documenting the upgrade in a video with a  part comparison at the end.

title: Extruder LED Strip Holder for Wanhao Duplicator i3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This model holds a standard 5×1 cm piece of 12V LED strip mounted to the front of the extruder bracket (which you can free up by moving the extruder fan to the back with the CiiiCoooler or Fan Duct.

The model is designed to be screwed to the extruder bracket using the original M3 screws, by tapping them directly into the plastic.

The LED strip must be 12V, and you can power it by wiring it parallel to the extruder fan (requires soldering, wires and JST PH connectors).

This model is available in two versions:

  • Extruder LED mount - more view.stl: this piece has smaller height, so it gives more view to the nozzle, however with this the heater block will slightly shadow the tip of the nozzle. (See the photo with the white piece.)
  • Extruder LED mount - no shadow.stl: this piece is taller, so it will not drop shadow to the nozzle, but it blocks more view. (See the photo with the black piece.)

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I recommend printing the model rotated to lay on its top, with the mounting holes vertical.

1. Lead the wires through the side hole of the model.
  2. Solder the wires to the LED strip.
  3. Pull back the wires and use the self adhesive on the back of the LED strip to glue it to the holder.
  4. Use M3 screws to mount the holder to the extruder assembly.
  5. Connect the other end of the wires as you wish to a 12V power supply (e.g. wire it parallel to the extruder fan).

Have fun!

title: Monoprice Select Mini Thumbwheel Leveling System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Update February 14, 2018
I've changed this from a work in progress to final. I do not plan on making any other changes to this system unless someone indicates a problem. Several have been successful with this system so I am making the move. Thanks to those that gave it a try in the beta stage!

Update: February 11, 2018
It was brought to my attention that the regular back bracket was missing the countersunk holes for the springs. I've updated the files and recommend everyone update that bracket with the newer file. The bracket without the countersunk is still usable if you use one of the the spring cup washers on the bottom.

Update: February 11, 2018
I've added a version of the front bracket with the magic number layer heights embossed in it. You can choose the original version or the magic number version as you please. No need to print both.

Update: February 10, 2018
I've added a back bracket with an integrated wire harness for those that choose to do the heat bed wire modification. You can use the same wheels with this bracket. It has a slot to hold a zip tie if you wish to secure your wires for strain relief. You choose which bracket you want to use. No need to print both.

Monoprice Select Mini Thumbwheel Leveling System
This is a thumb wheel leveling system I designed for the Monoprice Select Mini 3D Printer. This system is designed to be completely printable on the MP Select Mini and installed without any drilling or modification to the existing hardware. In doing this, the mod takes up some Z-height that you will lose for taller prints. The advantage of this system is that it is easily installed and removed if a larger Z-height is required.

Note: This is a prototype (Beta) leveling system that I may still tinker with based on recommendations and required improvements

Please follow the installation instructions below in order to be successful with this mod.
DO NOT attempt to print until you have installed the correctly sized provided spacer

Also, I HAVE NOT tested the z-spacers with a glass bed. Do so at your own risk

Parts List:

  • 4 M2 X 25mm screws to secure to the heat bed. I am currently using M2 X20mm screws and it does work, but you have more flexibility with the longer screws. DO NOT use M3 screws and DO NOT use the current screws used to hold the heat bed. They will not work. Must be M2. I used hex head M2 screws because that's what I had on hand, but you can use whichever head style you like. Countersunk style heads would probably be the best.

  • 4 M2 nylon lock nuts or lock washers. I prefer the lock nuts as they are more secure

  • 4 M2 nuts. 8 if you choose to go the lock washer route.

  • 8 M2 washers to prevent the M2 screws from falling through the heat bed screw holes.

  • Existing printer springs, cup washers and screws that secure the bed to the y-axis rods

Installation
Please reference the photos provided when putting together your system.

1.) Print all parts before assembly. DO NOT INSTALL ANY PARTS until you have printed out both the front and back brackets, the thumb wheels, and the necessary spacer.

2.) In order to print the brackets on the MP Select Mini, you will have to adjust your printer settings in Cura (or your particular slicer) to have an X and Y length of 125mm. This is not ideal as the official lengths are 120mm. But in order to print, we have to cheat a little and squeeze out a little more space. Reference the Cura photos. You most likley will not be able to fit a skirt or brim, so if you can print without. Please remember to put your settings back (X:120mm Y:120mm) when you are done. Alternately you can print the brackets on a larger printer.

3.) None of the parts require supports if oriented correctly in your slicer. The bracket should be printed as shown in the photo and the wheels face down.

4.) Thumb wheel assembly: The nuts will tightly fit within the hub of the wheels. You might have to tap them in a little to get them to seat properly. It is HIGHLY recommended that you super glue these in place. Please allot enough time for the glue to dry or the wheel will not be usable. You've been warned. Once the glue has dried, run an M2 screw through the nut a few times to make sure the inner threads of the nut are clear of dried glue. It might take some doing to clean it out but it's not too hard.

5.) Place the wheels into the slots of the brackets. The nut should be facing down.

6.) Attach screws to heat bed: The 4 M2 screws must be securely fastened to the heat bed so that they DO NOT TURN. This is accomplished with the nylon lock nuts or lock washers. Also secure existing cup washers as shown in the pictures. Use M2 washers on the top of the bed to prevent the screw head from falling through the screw hole.

7.) Screw brackets to the gantry. Remove the screws that hold the bed gantry to the y-axis rods. You can do this without harming anything. Just don't move the bed a bunch after you have unscrewed. Place the bracket on the bed and using the same screws, screw the bracket to the bed. Repeat for the other bracket. Please be careful that you install the correct brackets on the front and back.

8.) Assemble the heat bed: Place the heat bed on top of the brackets. The screws should line up with the center of the wheels. If they do not loosen them and re-align until they do. Place the existing 4 springs around the screws and make sure they seat into the depression of the brackets. Press down with the face of your hand on the heat bed until the screws seat with the top of the nuts in the thumb wheels. Turn each thumb wheel counter clockwise until the screw catches in the nut and it holds. At this point your heat bed should be securely fastened.

9.) Install the z-axis spacer: Lower the bed with the thumb wheels as low as they will go. Because the brackets add 12mm to the z-axis height, we have to adjust for this. 3 spacers are available for printing: 0mm offset, 3mm offset, and 4mm offset. The 0mm offset should be used by those that have not added a surface such as glass to the heat bed. BuildTak users, tape users, etc should use the 0 mm offset spacer. If you are using glass or another substrate choose the appropriate width (3mm or 4mm) for your application. Place the spacer as shown in the picture. The spacer clearly labels the correct orientation. It should snap into place.

10.) Level the bed: It is important to note that with this mod there is no play in the bed if the nozzle dives into it. PLEASE USE CARE WHEN HOMING THE NOZZLE AS TO NOT RUIN BOTH YOUR NOZZLE AND HEAT BED. With the bed lowered as low as it can go, home the printer. Be prepared to shut the printer off if you feel the nozzle is pressing to hard on the bed. From this point you should be able to adjust the thumb wheels to level the bed. Again, there is no play in the bed as there used to be. If the nozzle goes too low, it will dig into the bed causing damage. Be sure your leveling is spot on.

11.) THAT'S IT!

I hope you enjoy this mod. It makes leveling a snap and goes a lot quicker than using the Allen wrench. If anyone out there needs a different sized spacer, let me know. I can crank a new design out pretty fast.

As always, if you have any questions or concerns, post in the comments section and I'll get back to you.

DISCLAIMER: I am not responsible for any damage you cause to your printer if you choose to install this mod, whether you follow my directions or not. Install at your own risk. Pay close attention to the height of the bed prior to homing the printer so you don't do damage.

One last thing: If you are successful with this mod, please share a picture here. I would greatly appreciate it.

Happy Leveling!

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

comments.author: k2trf

comments.text: I had been thinking about doing something like this, but I had a far simpler idea. Tell me if you considered it or tried it first and ruled it out as unworkable. I would keep the original adjustment hardware and glue/weld the thumbscrew so it is midway between the two plates halfway down the screw. Then put in two springs--one above and one below the thumbscrew. Now, when you turned the wheel, it would turn the screw (just like using the allen wrench) to raise and lower the bed. See file attached.
comments.author: cjhilinski

comments.text: Why not just make the wheel just under the heat bed (print in ABS for heat resistance) Super glue it to the screw (making sure you're not gluing the screw to the bed. Even if the thumb wheel fails, just unscrew with the allen and reglue the wheel.
comments.author: cjhilinski

comments.text: I ended up taking an entirely different approach using aluminum. Basically, I extended the heated bed along the Y axis by adding two aluminum rails and moved the adjustment screws to the the edges of the lower bed. Here's a Fusion 360 pix. http://a360.co/2C4CL3q .
comments.author: LazaroFilm

comments.text: I think that would work.  I hadn't thought of that setup in particular.  The only thing that "might" concern me is the lateral stability of the bed with the longer screws but it may not be an issue.  Obviously the bed would be raised higher so you would still need a spacer on the z-axis.  I had thought about using a two spring setup to regain the play in the bed if the nozzle were to hit it.  But for my first go, I decided to go with the simpler approach used by a lot of other printers.

description.text:
Built my own version of an Ikea Lack enclosure for my MonoPrice Maker Select. I tried to keep the overall design as simple as possible. As a bonus I wanted to be able to control the LED lights remotely from OctoPrint. Using the System Command Editor plugin for OctoPrint along with the GPIO command from WiringPi I was able to control the lighting with a relay. To control the lights locally I added a momentary switch which communicates with a Python script running on the Raspberry Pi.

Lack Table: http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/40104270/

title: DFUNCT. 6 in 1 bowden Alpha DEFUNCT SEE New Original- thing:2801393

description.text:
Edit: Defunct, see new thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2801393

Edit: I've almost finished the new alpha scratch redo. I took some hints from the first design and matched the threading until it fit on my own. Should be a lot better than this one, once I get the cavity figured out, might even be done. Prototyping. 12/20/2018

Edit: Due to the narrow clearance, I'm recommending these push fittings: http://amzn.to/2HqPRYc. It's a problem that also exists on the original model with the regular brass connectors. Due to this I'm creating a new one from scratch but am getting my own threading correct. I'll post when I'm done which shouldn't be that long. I ran into this problem myself and apologize for any inconveniences.

Edit: Updated to Alpha 4. Fixed most of the overlap. Still small, small trouble but less than before, and even now. 2/6/2018

Edit: Left side m6 was reverse. Fixed seemingly.

Edit: There's a small overlap within the cavity but it's far less than a mm so I'm not too worried. Eventually I'll correct, but this is alpha and it should work fine.

This is an alpha of a bowden splitter to make your hotend accept 6 y extruders. This is a remix. It took an awful long time to create because of loading times due to the original model being made with a different program, so be a little thankful I guess.

I am not certain, but I recall somewhere someone may have been selling 5 in 1's. Well, here's another gift to the community. This is a remix so I'm more keen on giving the model to everyone. Should work on all bowden, if there's any changes needed, drop a comment.

I apologize for any uneven sections, it was incredibly difficult to edit this model because Fusion 360 didn't like the taste of it I take it. Don't mean to give excuses but the problems I could fix easily, if it weren't for the awful load times.

Thank you!

Fusion 360

This is a remix of thing: 1808035

Imported into 360. Converted from mesh to body. Casted the cavity. Manipulated cavity to have an extra bowden tube. Cut in half. Copied by moving and turning on axis to the blank other side. This prevented the bowden connectors from being mirrored. Created a casing. Cut cavity out of casing. Presto, a model.

This is a work in progress and I haven't fully tested it yet, but wanted to put it up in case it may be of use to someone else. It's just an adjustable Z axis endstop for the Monoprice Select Mini v2 that clips onto the vertical rod so no additional modifications are needed, and the only additional parts used are an M3 screw (~25-30mm) and a spring from a pen cut down to around 13mm (skinny spring, not the larger ones like in a G2). It doesn't offer a ton of range, maybe +/- a few mm, but that should be plenty for slight adjustments and tweaks between various filaments and build surface treatments.

Edit 02/23/18: Modified the mount to make the clip stronger.

I just sorted through 14 years worth of service records and dredged up some memories.

Just seemed right to whip this barrier up real quick tonight.

title: Replica Cortical Stack (From the Netflix series Altered Carbon)

description.text:
UPDATE 07/02/2018
Added extra stl file with cut throughs on the webbing per user request. Like the first stl file, print 2 copies to have both halves of the stack. Cut through version can be printed using opaque material.

This a quick STL model of the stacks as seen in the new Netflix series Altered Carbon, these stacks serve the purpose of holding human consciousness within the neck area as a means to surpass death of the body, so long as said stack is intact.

This model is an approximation of the stacks as seen in the series based on screen captures. For best results, print using a translucent material and use air brushing to create the metallic look. Keep the inside paint free as well as the areas that are supposed to glow.

The inside has a hallowed space, enough to fit a small 5v battery and some LED's in order to create the glowing effect within reason.

description.text:
A Kitty that can talk and sing without even asking for food?

Sample video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tAGdkvp6DdM

This is a Kitty version of the Google AIY Voice Kit.
I added a few custom commands like cat sounds, custom answers, play youtube music, move servos, etc.

The 3D model is based on Adafruit's Adabot, as they did an awesome job to mount the speaker and raspberry pi inside.
I changed the exterior and added a few modifications so the servos can fit.

Unfortunately the included speaker of the Google AIY Voice Kit is too big from the back, so I had to use another I had laying around from Adafruit.
You can buy it here: https://www.adafruit.com/product/1313

Use the same instructions for Adabot to put it together, and the Google AIY instructions (included in the magizine's kit) to mount the servos , you will probably have to solder them to the AIY voice hat.

Official AIY documentation: https://aiyprojects.withgoogle.com/voice/
Mods you can use: https://ktinkerer.co.uk/list-mods-raspberry-pi-aiy-project/

description.text:
So Joseph Zisa is either refusing to share CAD files of his v29 whistle or doesn't have those.
So I decided to make my own based on his.

This one is created from scratch, I only used general idea of Joseph Zisa for that design.

Please note that the license is different for this one:
It's either CC-BY-SA-4.0 (yes, this website claims it's 3.0, but I want it to be 4.0) or GNU GPL v3.
You can use it on terms of any of these licenses.
The main difference is that if you remix this thing — remix have to be licensed under one or both of these licenses.

Shape Is a bit different and there is no internal ribs so you can print it much faster without loosing any function (probably shouldn't print this without infill).
And it can be much lighter, thus allowing it to naturally stay afloat if printed with less infill.
It doesn't need all that extra weight from redundant ribs v29 have.

The sources is there:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/127002769eb5c2412870432a/w/84e3ee8687bc0f8d1c3acb2c/e/6e75b4f3ba9b11e85a305dd4
K, I printed and tested one.
In my ears it sounds way louder than v29.
Holy shit, it's ringing still.
Don't use it in enclosed room.

UPD: added branding and some details.
I am too lazy to make separate unbranded version.
You are totally allowed to make unbranded version.
You are even allowed to put any text or logo on it, just don't claim the authorship.

UPD1: added unbranded version for easier re-branding or just if you don't like having all this letters.

UPD2: tested it outside.
Bloody ginger, it's freaking loud.
Ears are ringing even though I was in open field.

UPD3: looks like onshape guys are changing the interface once again and export button for anonymous viewers moved to unknown place. Snapshots in every available format are added to the Thingiverse.

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 and higher

Infill:

10-100%

Notes:

Nozzle up to 0.6mm should be fine.
Infill is not required but highly recommended.
Material should not matter.

I tested it on 0.4×0.2 resolution with 20% infill, works fine and looks nice.

Version 1 worked technically but just made the mess land on the floor and not the bike. Also I could not see if fluid was coming out. I made changed in version 2 that helped a lot and makes it much easier to use. Not recommending printing this in white, makes it too hard to see the fluid. Maybe green or light blue. This version took almost 3x longer to print, 6 hrs to print at 50mms. There are improvement that can be done but I have no plans to implement them, the can angle can be relaxed to 22.5 degrees, a curved backstop for the chain, and slim it down a bit. For this version you need a 3mm x 15mm screw and nut

author: xKoldx

description.text:
This is a 3D printed case for a simple, pitch only theremin design known as the "Thierrymin", named after its designer Thierry Frenkel. The schematic and instructions can be found over at Theremin World at http://www.thereminworld.com/Forums/T/29231/my-new-year-gift-to-tw-a-new-theremin-circuit?Page=0.

I have included Thierry's schematic on this page, but strongly encourage you to head over to the thread linked above for more assembly and tuning instructions. This is a really simple circuit to assemble, and a lot of fun to play with.

I have also added a small 2W speaker and an LM386 amplifier. I have also included a schematic showing how this amplifier is wired.

In addition to the parts Thierry lists on the schematic, you will also need the following parts for use with this 3D printed case:

  • 50mm x 80mm breadboard. I used the one from BusBoard (model PAD1), available from Mouser or Digikey
  • 10K 16mm rotary potentiometer
  • 36mm diameter 8 Ohm speaker (see picture)
  • 1/4" Mono Switched Phone Connector
  • Round rocker switch (20mm diam hole)
  • LM386 amplifier
  • 4mm banana socket jack (or similar) for grounding connector
  • 9V battery connector
  • 50cm, 6mm diam telescopic antenna, with 3mm thread. I've included a picture. Mine was actually 47cm from uxcell, and worked just fine.
  • 12mm M3 bolts and nuts
  • Side-facing variable capacitor (see below)

The schematic calls for a 4-22 pF variable capacitor. I recommend using a capacitor that faces to the side, so it can be adjusted after the box is closed. The case design includes a hole on the left side, and the capacitor will need to be aligned with this hole. I used the Sprague Goodman GYD40000 3.5 - 40 pF capacitor, available at Mouser, which did the trick. If using the same capacitor, place it in the upper left corner of the breadboard, facing left, with the center lined up with the 5th row from the top of the board (see photo).

This unit is designed to be powered off of a 9V battery. That said, it works best when grounded. If you are connecting to an external amplifier using the 1/4" jack, it is likely that the shield is already grounded. However, if you are using the speaker on the unit, you may find that a grounded connection gets better performance. In the photo, you will see a green banana jack on the back for this purpose. I connected that to a modified wall plug with only the ground connected.

The case needs to be printed with internal supports, due to the antenna mount. M3 nuts hold the lid in place. To insert the nuts, use a long M3 bold through the hole in the case, thread the nut into the bolt, and pull up (or tighten). They should be held in place with friction until the lid is installed.

Last, the speaker can be held in place with hot glue (see photo). Enjoy!

description.text:
This was designed around a Wheels Mfg Threaded-in PF30 bottom bracket. You need 2 tools to tighten it in and I did not feel like buying another Park BBT-29 tool. I used the park tool to torque down and this tool to hold the other side. I added (4) 3mm x 18mm pins I got off Amazon but I think for how i used it, all plastic would have worked. I do not know if it is strong enough for 35-50nm of torque.

Its a tight fit in Petg, in my experience PLA shrinks a bit more so best to print it upside down for a couple of millimeters and check fit. Scale up as needed. I included a deeper version for those who would want to use it on a Mega BB, it a totally untested design.

author: RiversCo

title: Ohio State's Tom W. Davis Clock Tower

description.text:
A replica of the infamous Tom W. Davis clock tower at The Ohio State University. When the clock tower finished construction in late 2017, its glory was hailed by all who were blessed enough to walk in its presence. Now you can have your very own Tom W. Davis clock tower to defeat your enemies and make all of your friends jealous.

Modeled in Solidworks based on a photograph of the tower, at about 1:200 scale.

To print the basic no-frills geometry of the tower, just print tomWDavisTower.STL.

To print the fully detailed tower, print clockTowerDetailed.STL and all of the accessories (clock face, clock needle pin, minute hand, and hour hand). The clock face and clock hands attach to the tower through friction-fit pins. With a good print resolution and maybe a little sanding, the clock hands should even turn.

If you have a small printer like I do, there are also files for the tower split in half vertically, and a pin to connect them.

description.text:
Hello! I've recently completed doing the AM8 upgrade to my Anet A8, and needed a replacement spool holder for it.
I didn't want one that needed screws, and I wanted to have more than 1 spool on it.

So I found the one remixed by denos, and modified it a bit so that it could be used like you see in the picture!

The STL I've provided works with 608 sized bearings (The ones people used in fidget spinners)
I've changed the model a bit from the picture by cutting off a bit from the top so the bearing can be flush with the print, instead of 4mm inside, or having space inside. This way it will be MUCH easier to align them :)

These are the rods I got https://goo.gl/2SzxDR
You can really get which ever length of rods you want, but if you're going bigger, you should probably go with a higher infill percentage.

I've also shared an end cap for the 8mm rods.
While they'd likely work with hard plastic, I printed mine out of TPU so that it'd be easy to put on and take off.
I'd recommend printing these so that if your printer isn't leveled, the spools on the ends won't slide off.

author: galaverse

title: Martian 2 GoPro (20 degree or 35) - Semi universal

description.text:
This is a martian 2 HD box camera (Gopro, runcam 3, and I think the foxeer box is similar size too...) The first design the tolerances to keep the camera inside were not enough, and it was a little lose, but fit well. I have increased the top and bottom lips and the side, and reversed my original internal chamfer to be an external chamfer to help get the camera in, but increase retention.

I have added ziptie slots for added strength to hold it to your frame as well as the ability to move it between frames, and potentially only screw in 2 of the screws, and zip tie it down. This design is VERY light, but still provides good protection for the camera glass. There is a 20 degree and 35 degree version. I would highly recommend printing right side up for best layer strength for the screws.

Print it with supports.

remixed_from.author: mrandyvalentine
remixed_from.title: Mastercrafted Wolven Steel Sword - The Witcher

title: Mastercrafted Wolven Steel Sword (v2) & Scabbard - The Witcher

description.text:
About The Model

After getting a lot of feedback about version 1 of this sword (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2761042), I've made a number of changes and improvements with this version 2 to make a model that easier to print and construct.

Support Me

Though I provide this print for free, if you'd like to shout me a coffee or support my work (Patreon's will get future files earlier than everyone else) - all of which helps me create more of these free models - you can do so on the following links:

  • Ko-fi: https://ko-fi.com/valentinecostumes
  • Patreon: https://patreon.com/valentinecostumes

Updates from v1

  • Blade width increased from 6mm to 9mm for extra strength and to allow wider cores to be used.
  • If you intended to use this model in it's "break apart for transportation" mode, you'll now need a 5mm x 6mm binding screw for the hole in BLADE 1.stl
  • Space for the metal core now runs the full length of the blade (intended use: two 3mm x 10mm x 600mm steel rods)
  • Tolerances for carbon rods now widened for easier fitting (intended use: two 2.5mm x 1m or four 2.5mm x 500mm rods)
  • Tolerances for the connections between the parts of the hilt widened for easier fitting.
  • BLADE 1 - NO HOLE.stl provided for those who don't want to make it break apart.
  • Crossguard tips are now a separate modal so that you have no overhang issues with the print.
  • Runes now cut slightly wider and deeper so that they're more visible after painting / finishing or can be painted with a colour more easily.
  • Updated the pommel file to fix an issue where the wolf was detaching from the base.
  • Scabbard now also included - this is intended to be covered in a 1.5mm leather outer (which will help it all stay together).

Commissions

If you're interesting in commissioning another sword from the Witcher series, a version of this sword with your own choice of rune text, or any other file, feel free to contact me on here.

Socials

You can follow me and my work on the following sites:

  • Instagram
  • Facebook
  • Twitter

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

Print one of all pieces, and two of POMMEL x2.stl

If you want to make it break apart, print BLADE 1.stl. If you want to make it so the blade and hilt are fixed in place, print BLADE 1 - NO HOLE.stl.

Supports should only be required on the pommels which should be printing on their back.

Sometimes the CROSSGUARD END pieces can be tricky to print flat. Depending how your layering application loads the file, it's worth noting that the 5 sides are in 72 degree increments. A rotation of this amount should allow you to properly flatten it with the extrusion pointing upwards

This is the paste extruder I designed for flyingbear tornado.
Syringue:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/150ML-Transparent-Reusable-Large-Big-Plastic-Hydroponics-Nutrient-Measuring-Syringe/32845092700.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.dbLT2w
Ball screw:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-T8-Lead-screw-300-mm-8mm-brass-copper-nut-KP08-or-KFL08-bearing-Bracket/32596099063.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.tIquex
Bearing: extracted from ball screw kit
Linear rail:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Top-Quality-4pcs-OD-8mm-x-500mm-Cylinder-Liner-Rail-Linear-Shaft-Optical-Axis-chrome-For/32765021606.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.tIquex
Linear bearing (4 parts needed):
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-Shipping-12pcs-lot-LM8UU-8mm-Linear-Bushing-CNC-Linear-Bearings/32434013744.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.wu3MNC
Stepper motor:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/42-Stepper-Motor-Nema-17-4-Lead-42BYGH-1-7A-17HS4401S-with-4-Pin-Dupont-Cable/32814608446.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.wu3MNC

Note: in order to keep same firmware for both filament and past extruder I trick filament diameter. Indeed, a parameter from firmware set the length extruded per step motor. This parameter should change depending on the changing of extruder.
This tricking is simple: putting a corrected diameter of filament in cura (different than syringue inside diameter) in orderto correct extruder "wrong" parameter.
I hope you get it.
This calculation is in calculation file included. Please confirm my calculation.

title: Skier remix - straight skis and symmetrical

description.text:
I needed a basic ski jumper that can go down a ramp, so I split the Basic Skier Figurine model by independencetech down the middle and mirrored the better half.

You can see my work in this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MbvrLyKXNBw
